questions.text:
Ten days after a motor vehicle collision, a 28-year-old man develops jaundiced skin. Upon initial presentation for his injuries, the patient was taken for an emergency laparotomy, which revealed significant internal hemorrhage from blunt abdominal trauma to the spleen. He required rapid transfusion with a total of 7 units of packed red blood cells. He has recovered well from the procedure until this morning, when he began to develop jaundiced skin and sclerae. He does not have pruritus. He has had no prior surgeries and takes no other medications. He is sexually active with one female partner. Prior to the accident, he drank 4 beers per day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination is limited due to pain. There are no palpable abdominal masses. There is a midline surgical scar with no erythema, purulence, or drainage. He has healing abrasions on the upper left side of his face and bruises over the anterior abdomen. CT scan shows a resolving hematoma in the peritoneal cavity. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.7 g/dL


Hematocrit
30%


Leukocyte count
7000/mm3



Platelet count
135,000/mm3



Serum



 Total bilirubin
3.9 mg/dL


 Indirect bilirubin

3.7 mg/dL


 Direct bilirubin
0.2 mg/dL


 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
60 U/L


 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
92 U/L


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's jaundice?

choices.text: Decreased hepatic uptake of unconjugated bilirubin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Biliary obstruction, which can be caused by choledocholithiasis, pancreatic masses, or primary sclerosing cholangitis, leads to an increase in conjugated, rather than unconjugated, bilirubin. In addition, blunt abdominal trauma rarely causes biliary obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

The liver and spleen are the most commonly injured solid organs in patients who have sustained blunt abdominal trauma. Though this patient has a mild increase in transaminase concentrations, which may indicate some injury to the liver, hepatocellular injury generally results in a mixed conjugated and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to interference in uptake, conjugation, and excretion of bilirubin.

C) CORRECT:

Reabsorption of blood from a hematoma (e.g., in trauma patients or postsurgical patients) involves the breakdown of hemoglobin, which is metabolized into bilirubin before being transported to the liver to be conjugated with glucuronic acid to become water-soluble. Increased formation of bilirubin results in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrahepatic cholestasis is caused by various conditions, including viral hepatitis, alcohol-associated hepatitis, and primary biliary cholangitis. Intrahepatic cholestasis causes an increase in conjugated bilirubin, not unconjugated bilirubin.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired conjugation of bilirubin is seen in patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome, both of which are congenital conditions that impair intrahepatic conjugation of bilirubin with glucuronic acid. Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a rare disease that typically causes severe jaundice and neurologic impairment in newborns; this condition is unlikely in this adult patient with asymptomatic jaundice. Gilbert syndrome can manifest later in life, but this patient's recent history of blunt abdominal trauma with a resolving hematoma on CT scan makes another cause of jaundice more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased hepatic uptake of unconjugated bilirubin can occur in patients with congestive heart failure, portosystemic shunts, and, rarely, Gilbert syndrome. Although these conditions can also cause an isolated increase in unconjugated bilirubin, they are unlikely in this young patient who has no history of cardiovascular or hepatobiliary disease.
questions.hint: This patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia 10 days after significant internal hemorrhage from blunt abdominal trauma. The underlying cause involves reabsorption of the hematoma in his peritoneal cavity.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of yellow discoloration of her skin, loss of appetite, and 3 episodes of vomiting. Her parents also report darkening of her urine and light stools. During the last 2 days, the girl has been scratching her abdomen and arms and has been crying excessively. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Her family emigrated from Japan 8 years ago. Immunizations are up-to-date. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of her skin and sclerae. Abdominal examination shows a mass in the right upper abdomen. Serum studies show:


Bilirubin (total)
5 mg/dL


Direct
4.2 mg/dL


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
40 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
60 U/L


γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT)
110 U/L (N = 5–50)


Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the gallbladder and a fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic common bile duct. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Biliary cysts (i.e., choledochal cysts) are most commonly seen in patients of Asian descent and appear as saccular or fusiform dilations of the biliary tree or as dilated masses that communicate with the biliary tree. A biliary cyst can result in cholestatic jaundice, abdominal pain, and a palpable right upper quadrant mass and, if left untreated, increases the risk of cholangitis and malignancy (e.g., cholangiocarcinoma, pancreatic cancer, gallbladder cancer). In rare cases, a biliary cyst may involve the cystic duct and result in gallbladder dilation. The recommended treatment for a biliary cyst is surgical excision of the cyst, followed by the creation of a biliary-enteric anastomosis with a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.

B) INCORRECT:

Mirizzi syndrome would result in cholestatic jaundice and dilation of the gallbladder and extrahepatic bile ducts on ultrasound. However, gallstone disease is rare in children unless risk factors such as chronic hemolytic anemia (e.g., hereditary spherocytosis) are present.

C) INCORRECT:

Biliary atresia would manifest with cholestatic jaundice. However, jaundice usually develops within the first few weeks of life, and dilation of the gallbladder or extrahepatic bile ducts would not be expected. Instead, ultrasound would reveal atresia of the extrahepatic bile ducts and typically a small or absent gallbladder.

D) INCORRECT:

Caroli disease would result in cholestatic jaundice, but the gallbladder and extrahepatic bile duct would not be dilated on ultrasound. Instead, multiple saccular dilations of the intrahepatic bile ducts could be seen.

E) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic pseudocysts, which develop 2–4 weeks following acute pancreatitis, can be associated with nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. A pseudocyst at the head of the pancreas can also compress the biliary tree and result in cholestatic jaundice. However, there is no history of acute pancreatitis in this toddler. Moreover, acute pancreatitis is very rare in children; it typically occurs among adults with risk factors such as alcohol use disorder and gallstone disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Alagille syndrome can result in cholestatic jaundice. However, this condition is not associated with a right upper quadrant mass or dilation of the gallbladder and extrahepatic bile ducts. Moreover, the onset of jaundice typically occurs before the age of 6 months, and other features, such as broad nasal bridge, triangular facies, deep-set eyes, a posterior embryotoxon, and/or murmurs of congenital heart defects, would be expected.

G) INCORRECT:

Type 2 Crigler-Najjar syndrome may manifest with jaundice in a 2-year-old child. However, the condition would cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia rather than conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and clinical features of cholestasis (e.g., pruritus, acholic stools, dark urine) would not be expected.
questions.hint: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, dark urine, acholic stools, and pruritus indicates cholestasis. The cause of cholestasis is evident from the findings of physical examination and ultrasonography.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of intermittent epigastric discomfort. He reports that his urine has been very dark, and his stools have been pale for the past week. His appetite has decreased, and he has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss during this period. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks a few shots of vodka daily. He has chronic left knee pain, for which he takes acetaminophen. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and scleral icterus. There are scratch marks on the extremities. Abdominal examination shows a nontender, palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8,700/mm3



Platelet count
172,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
17 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 Bilirubin



 Total
6 mg/dL


 Direct

5.2 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
220 IU/L


Ultrasonography shows dilated extrahepatic and pancreatic ducts and a distended gall bladder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with late-stage alcohol-associated liver disease often develop manifestations of liver failure, such as jaundice. However, laboratory studies in alcohol-associated liver disease would show indirect hyperbilirubinemia. Other possible findings include hypoalbuminemia and subsequent ascites. Abdominal examination shows hepatomegaly or a cirrhotic liver. The double duct sign (which indicates biliary and pancreatic duct obstruction) is not present in patients with alcohol-associated liver disease.

B) CORRECT:

Courvoisier sign raises suspicion for pancreatic malignancy. This patient's history of smoking is a risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma, which manifests with biliary tract obstruction as a late sign of infiltrative disease. A stenosing tumor in the pancreatic head causes subsequent prestenotic dilation, which appears as dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts (the double duct sign) on ultrasonography. Significant weight loss is another classic symptom of a malignant process.
Image Description:

Tumors of the pancreatic head may obstruct the extrahepatic bile ducts and pancreatic duct. Bile duct obstruction results in Courvoisier sign (painless jaundice plus an enlarged, nontender gallbladder on palpation), pale stools, dark urine, and pruritus. Pancreatic duct obstruction results in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency and steatorrhea. The obstruction-related dilation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct demonstrates as the double-duct sign on radiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute acetaminophen-induced liver injury is caused by ingestion of toxic amounts of the drug (> 4000 mg/day). As a result of hepatocellular toxicity, patients present with acute liver failure (nausea, vomiting, jaundice, coagulation disturbance, encephalopathy, highly elevated transaminases), which is most severe within 96 hours of ingestion. Subacute onset of jaundice, weight loss, double duct sign (dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts), and lack of encephalopathy are all inconsistent with acute acetaminophen toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis can develop cholestatic jaundice as a result of bile duct fibrosis. On ERCP, the bile duct typically has a beaded appearance, which indicates strictures alternating with dilated segments of the duct. However, this patient has a double duct sign (dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts) on ultrasonography, which indicates a localized obstruction at a level proximal to the major duodenal papilla.

E) INCORRECT:

Choledocholithiasis often manifests with acute jaundice, nausea, vomiting, and severe colicky abdominal pain associated with eating. Acute cholecystitis, a common complication of gallstones, can manifest with a Murphy sign. However, the Courvoisier sign is not present in either condition. In addition, this patient's subacute painless jaundice is more consistent with another disease process.

F) INCORRECT:

Hemolysis can manifest with fulminant, painless jaundice, and anemia. In patients with hereditary red blood cell membrane defects (e.g., hereditary spherocytosis), hemolysis can result from an acute oxidative stress response (e.g., infection), which is not evident from this patient's recent medical history. In addition, patients with hemolytic anemia develop indirect hyperbilirubinemia, not direct hyperbilirubinemia.

G) INCORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis manifests with intermittent epigastric abdominal pain. Common risk factors for pancreatitis include chronic alcohol consumption and smoking. However, weight loss in patients with chronic pancreatitis is the result of chronic maldigestion and manifests with steatorrhea and malabsorption. While concurrent chronic pancreatitis cannot be entirely excluded in this patient, jaundice is not a common finding in patients with chronic pancreatitis. Moreover, this condition does not cause a double duct sign (dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts) on ultrasonography.
Image Description:

In chronic pancreatitis, inflammation and fibrosis of pancreatic tissue can manifest with abdominal pain (main symptom), which is often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Symptoms of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., steatorrhea, weight loss) and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency (pancreatic diabetes) typically occur late when more than 90% of pancreatic tissue is destroyed.
questions.hint: This patient presents with Courvoisier sign (jaundice and a nontender, palpable gall bladder). Pale stools, dark urine, pruritus (suggested by the scratch marks on this patient's extremities), and direct hyperbilirubinemia indicate posthepatic jaundice.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his skin and generalized pruritus. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and scleral icterus. Urinalysis shows an elevated concentration of bilirubin and a low concentration of urobilinogen. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?

choices.text: Malignant growth in the pancreatic body
Presence of stones within the gallbladder

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which is seen in Gilbert syndrome and Crigler-Najjar syndrome. While affected patients may present with jaundice and pruritus, bilirubin would not be detected in the urine. Moreover, the relatively acute course of this patient's symptoms makes this unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemolysis can also cause jaundice and pruritus, which are seen here. In hemolysis, destruction of RBCs leads to excess unconjugated bilirubin in the serum and other laboratory signs of hemolysis, as well as increased excretion of conjugated bilirubin by the intestines. Urinalysis would be expected to show increased urobilinogen (due to increased conversion from conjugated bilirubin to urobilinogen in the gut, intestinal reabsorption, and renal excretion) and normal bilirubin, unlike with this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic head tumors commonly present with jaundice, given their proximity to the biliary tree and subsequent potential for biliary duct obstruction. However, pancreatic body tumors are uncommon and much less likely to affect the liver or cause bile duct obstruction. This pathology is therefore an unlikely cause of this patient's features.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased intestinal bilirubin reabsorption would result in increased levels of conjugated bilirubin (conjugated hyperbilirubinemia). While this excess of bilirubin can lead to acute jaundice and pruritus, urinalysis would show both increased bilirubin and urobilinogen excretion. This patient's urinalysis shows a low concentration of urobilinogen, which implies his conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is due to a different cause.

E) CORRECT:

Normally, unconjugated bilirubin is absorbed by the liver and conjugated with glucuronic acid. It is then secreted via the bile and converted to urobilinogen by intestinal bacteria. In cases of defective hepatic bile excretion (i.e., due to a bile duct stenosis or choledocholithiasis), conjugation continues to take place (i.e., unconjugated bilirubin concentration remains normal) but conjugated bilirubin cannot be secreted. Conjugated bilirubin accumulates in the blood (conjugated hyperbilirubinemia) and is excreted by the kidneys (increased bilirubin in urinalysis).
Image Description:

(1) Hemoglobin is broken down into heme and globin in the spleen and, to a lesser extent, in the bone marrow.
(2) Macrophages break heme down into unconjugated bilirubin. Bound to albumin, unconjugated bilirubin is transported in the bloodstream and taken up by the liver.
(3) Bilirubin is conjugated in the liver and secreted in bile.
(4) In order to be secreted, conjugated bilirubin enters the blood to reach the hepatocytes with a direct connection to the bile canaliculi. At this stage, conjugated bilirubin is detectable in the blood.
(5) Bilirubin reaches the intestine via the bile. Intestinal bacteria convert bilirubin to urobilinogen.
(6) Most of the urobilinogen is converted into stercobilinogen and then stercobilin. Stercobilin is excreted via the stool, giving it its characteristic brown color.
(7) A smaller portion of urobilinogen is reabsorbed and follows two different paths:
→ (8) Most of it undergoes hepatobiliary recirculation, while the rest is filtrated in the kidney.
→ Or: (9) The remainder gets filtrated in the kidneys. in the urine, urobilinogen is oxidized to urobilin, which is responsible for the characteristic yellow color.

F) INCORRECT:

Gallstones located in the gallbladder do not lead to hyperbilirubinemia. Only a patient with a gallstone obstructing biliary outflow would be symptomatic, in which case jaundice, pruritus, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia would be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's bilirubinuria suggests an underlying conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, as unconjugated bilirubin is tightly bound to albumin and cannot be filtered and excreted in the urine.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of an 8-hour history of abdominal pain and nausea. The pain worsened after she ate a sandwich, and she has vomited once. She has no history of serious medical illness. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.1°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 134/83 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and diffuse tenderness in the upper abdomen. Serum studies show:


Total bilirubin
2.7 mg/dL


AST
35 U/L


ALT
38 U/L


Alkaline phosphatase
180 U/L


γ-Glutamyltransferase
90 U/L (N = 5–50)


Ultrasonography is most likely to show a stone located in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Choledocholithiasis is the presence of gallstones in the common bile duct and is most commonly a result of the passage of gallstones from the gallbladder. This patient's signs and symptoms are due to common bile duct obstruction (leading to elevated parameters of cholestasis such as γ-glutamyltransferase, alkaline phosphatase, and direct bilirubin) and consequent biliary tract spasms. In addition to the occluding gallstone, ultrasonography typically shows a dilated common bile duct with possible intrahepatic biliary dilatation. Choledocholithiasis is treated with spasmolytics, analgesia, and removal of the stone, usually via ERCP. An elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy is commonly indicated to prevent a recurrence.
Image Description:

The right and left hepatic ducts join to form the common hepatic duct. The cystic duct joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct. The main pancreatic duct drains into the common bile duct. The common bile duct opens into the descending part of the duodenum.

B) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the common hepatic duct can manifest with abdominal pain, scleral icterus, and elevated parameters of cholestasis, all of which are seen here. However, common hepatic duct obstruction is rarely due to intraluminal gallstones; rather, it is caused by extrinsic compression by a gallstone impacted in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck (i.e., Mirizzi syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

A gallstone obstructing the cystic duct can cause acute cholecystitis, which typically manifests with postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, all of which are seen here. This patient, however, does not present with classic features of acute cholecystitis, such as fever and a positive Murphy sign. In addition, scleral icterus, and elevated parameters of cholestasis are uncommon in uncomplicated acute cholecystitis because the flow of bile from the liver into the duodenum is usually not obstructed.
Image Description:

The illustration shows gallstones within the gallbladder and gallbladder wall inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

A gallstone obstructing the gallbladder neck can cause acute cholecystitis, which typically manifests with postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, all of which are seen here. This patient, however, does not present with classic features of acute cholecystitis, such as fever and a positive Murphy sign. In addition, scleral icterus, and elevated parameters of cholestasis are uncommon in uncomplicated acute cholecystitis because the flow of bile from the liver into the duodenum is usually not obstructed.

E) INCORRECT:

Cholelithiasis is the presence of gallstones in the gallbladder (e.g., the fundus). Cholelithiasis is usually asymptomatic but can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, all of which are seen here. However, pain lasting for more than 6 hours, scleral icterus, and elevated parameters of cholestasis are inconsistent with cholelithiasis.
Image Description:

Cholelithiasis: the presence of gallstones within the gall bladder
Cholangitis: ascending biliary tract infection (orange shading) secondary to choledocholithiasis
Biliary pancreatitis: Pancreatic outflow obstruction secondary to choledocholithiasis allows for activation of pancreatic zymogens, resulting in pancreatic inflammation (orange shading).

F) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the pancreatic duct can cause acute pancreatitis, which can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and, in the case of concomitant biliary obstruction, scleral icterus and elevated parameters of cholestasis. However, when pancreatitis is caused by a gallstone, the gallstone is stuck in the common bile duct just past the ampulla of Vater, not inside the pancreatic duct.
questions.hint: This patient presents with biliary colic (postprandial, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting). The prolonged episode of pain, signs of extrahepatic cholestasis (scleral icterus, elevated parameters of cholestasis), and absence of fever indicate choledocholithiasis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and yellowish discoloration of her skin. During this period, she has also had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight gain. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine daily. She follows a vegan diet that consists mainly of spinach, kale, and sweet potatoes. Physical examination shows yellowing of the skin. Her hands are cold to the touch and her nails appear brittle. Eye examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient's serum?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased haptoglobin concentration occurs in hemolysis, which results in yellow skin discoloration through deposition of bilirubin, a degradation product of hemoglobin, in the subcutaneous fat tissue. This patient also presents with fatigue, which can be caused by hemolytic anemia. However, unlike this patient's presentation, hyperbilirubinemia would lead to jaundice of the sclerae and mucous membranes before affecting the skin.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP) concentration occurs in obstructive jaundice, which also leads to yellow skin discoloration through the accumulation of bilirubin in the subcutaneous fat tissue. However, hyperbilirubinemia would also cause jaundice of the sclerae and mucous membranes (before it is visible on the skin), which this patient notably lacks. Additionally, typical signs of cholestasis such as pale stools, dark urine, pruritus, and symptoms of fat malabsorption (e.g., steatorrhea, weight loss) are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies are present in patients with primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC), which leads to intrahepatic cholestasis (due to the destruction of the intrahepatic bile ducts) and yellow discoloration of the skin from bilirubin deposition in the subcutaneous fat tissue. This patient's fatigue, age, gender, and (likely autoimmune) hypothyroidism suggest PBC. However, the hyperbilirubinemia seen in PBC would cause jaundice of the sclerae and mucous membranes before visibly affecting the skin.

D) CORRECT:

Increased beta-carotene concentration causes pseudojaundice, which manifests with yellow discoloration of the skin, especially in the hands, soles, forehead, and nose because beta-carotene accumulates in the skin's epidermis; the sclerae and mucous membranes are spared, as seen here. Carotenemia can result from excessive consumption of sweet potatoes, leafy greens, carrots, and oranges; increased intake of carotene-rich supplements may also cause carotenemia. This patient's weight gain, fatigue, brittle nails, and cold skin indicates hypothyroidism, which leads to reduced production of vitamin A from beta-carotene due to lack of thyroxine, thereby further increasing beta-carotene levels.
Image Description:

The orange discoloration of the palm stands in stark contrast to the nondiscolored skin of the shoulder in the background.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-HAV IgM antibodies indicate a hepatitis A infection, which leads to yellow discoloration of the skin through bilirubin deposition in the subcutaneous fat tissue. However, unlike this patient's presentation, hyperbilirubinemia would lead to jaundice of sclerae and mucous membranes before visibly affecting the skin. Additionally, this patient lacks other symptoms of hepatitis A, such as fever, nausea, anorexia, and right upper quadrant pain.
questions.hint: Notably, this patient does not present with scleral icterus.

questions.text:
A 28-day-old male infant (who is the child of two healthy parents) presents for a one-month well-child visit. He was born full term by vaginal delivery, without complications, and was discharged home from the nursery at 48 hours old. At 72 hours of life, he was noted to be significantly jaundiced, and his total bilirubin level was 19.0 mg/dL (reference range, <11.5). He was directly admitted to the hospital, where he was treated with phototherapy for 24 hours, with improvement of his bilirubin to 13 mg/dL. During this admission, his blood type was found to be O+, a direct antiglobulin test was negative, and a complete blood count did not show anemia. After 36 hours of phototherapy, he was discharged home, hydrated, tolerating breastfeeding well, and appearing well.
Today, his mother is concerned because he continues to appear jaundiced. He continues to breastfeed exclusively, which is going well. He has gained more than 25 grams per day during the past week, has surpassed his birth weight, and is producing more than five wet diapers and stools per day. He has had no fevers, and no one is sick at home.
On physical examination, he is tired but arousable and appears nontoxic. He is visibly jaundiced from head to groin. There is no cephalohematoma, bruising, or other signs of trauma and no rashes. Cardiac examination is unremarkable, and the rest of the examination is normal.
His total bilirubin level is 20.3 mg/dL (reference range, <1.2), with a direct bilirubin level of 0.9 mg/dL (<0.2) and normal aminotransferase levels. His hemoglobin concentration has been stable since the initial hospital admission. His newborn screen is confirmed to be normal.
What is the best next step to establish a cause for this patient’s hyperbilirubinemia?

choices.text: Genetic sequencing of the uridine diphosphoglucuronate-glucuronosyltransferase 1A1 (UGT1A1) gene

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This infant presents with significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that is worsening after a prior hospitalization for phototherapy immediately after birth. He appears well otherwise, has no known risk factors for hemolysis, and has already had an unrevealing basic workup for neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, including an infant blood type, complete blood count, and direct antiglobulin test. Given this information and the persistent hyperbilirubinemia, inherited disorders of bilirubin conjugation should be considered as a potential cause of this infant’s jaundice. Mutations in the UGT1A1 gene are associated with Gilbert syndrome and Crigler-Najjar syndrome types 1 and 2, all of which can manifest with varying levels of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Key learning point: The test that should be considered in a well-appearing infant with persistent unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia beyond the second week of life is genetic sequencing of the UGT1A1 gene.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated urine coproporphyrins are characteristically found in Dubin-Johnson syndrome, a disorder of bilirubin excretion. However, this disorder would manifest with conjugated (not unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia.

C) INCORRECT:

An abdominal ultrasound can be useful in evaluating an infant for cholestasis and could reveal a choledochal cyst or suggest biliary atresia. Cholestasis should always be suspected in patients with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (defined as a direct bilirubin concentration >1 mg/dL). However, in this patient, the direct bilirubin level is <1 mg/dL, which argues against cholestasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobinopathies, such as sickle cell disease, can manifest with hyperbilirubinemia in a neonate. However, this infant has no reported family history to suggest sickle cell disease as a potential source, and other, more common causes of severe hyperbilirubinemia should be considered first. Hemoglobin electrophoresis may be considered if a patient does not respond well to therapy, if anemia is evident on complete blood count, or if the newborn-screen results raise concerns.

E) INCORRECT:

A hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan can be useful in evaluating an infant for cholestasis and could reveal a choledochal cyst or suggest biliary atresia. Cholestasis should always be suspected in patients with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (defined as a direct bilirubin concentration >1 mg/dL). However, in this patient, the direct bilirubin level is <1 mg/dL, which argues against cholestasis.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-week history of intermittent epigastric discomfort. He reports that his urine has been very dark, and his stools have been pale for the past week. His appetite has decreased, and he has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss during this period. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and scleral icterus. There are scratch marks on the extremities. Abdominal examination shows a nontender, palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Bilirubin



 Total
6 mg/dL


 Direct

5.2 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
220 IU/L


Ultrasonography shows dilated extrahepatic and pancreatic ducts and a distended gall bladder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with late-stage alcohol-associated liver disease often develop manifestations of liver failure, such as jaundice. However, this patient does not have a history of consuming alcohol and laboratory studies in alcohol-associated liver disease would show indirect hyperbilirubinemia. Other possible findings include hypoalbuminemia and subsequent ascites. Abdominal examination shows hepatomegaly or a cirrhotic liver. The double duct sign (which indicates biliary and pancreatic duct obstruction) is not present in patients with alcohol-associated liver disease.

B) CORRECT:

Courvoisier sign raises suspicion for pancreatic malignancy. This patient's history of smoking is a risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma, which manifests with biliary tract obstruction as a late sign of infiltrative disease. A stenosing tumor in the pancreatic head causes subsequent prestenotic dilation, which appears as dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts (the double duct sign) on ultrasonography. Significant weight loss is another classic symptom of a malignant process.
Image Description:

Tumors of the pancreatic head may obstruct the extrahepatic bile ducts and pancreatic duct. Bile duct obstruction results in Courvoisier sign (painless jaundice plus an enlarged, nontender gallbladder on palpation), pale stools, dark urine, and pruritus. Pancreatic duct obstruction results in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency and steatorrhea. The obstruction-related dilation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct demonstrates as the double-duct sign on radiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis can develop cholestatic jaundice as a result of bile duct fibrosis. On ERCP, the bile duct typically has a beaded appearance, which indicates strictures alternating with dilated segments of the duct. However, this patient has a double duct sign (dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts) on ultrasonography, which indicates a localized obstruction at a level proximal to the major duodenal papilla.

D) INCORRECT:

Choledocholithiasis often manifests with acute jaundice, nausea, vomiting, and severe colicky abdominal pain associated with eating. Acute cholecystitis, a common complication of gallstones, can manifest with a Murphy sign. However, the Courvoisier sign is not present in either condition. In addition, this patient's subacute painless jaundice is more consistent with another disease process.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis manifests with intermittent epigastric abdominal pain. Common risk factors for pancreatitis include chronic alcohol consumption and smoking. However, weight loss in patients with chronic pancreatitis is the result of chronic maldigestion and manifests with steatorrhea and malabsorption. While concurrent chronic pancreatitis cannot be entirely excluded in this patient, jaundice is not a common finding in patients with chronic pancreatitis. Moreover, this condition does not cause a double duct sign (dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts) on ultrasonography.
Image Description:

In chronic pancreatitis, inflammation and fibrosis of pancreatic tissue can manifest with abdominal pain (main symptom), which is often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Symptoms of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., steatorrhea, weight loss) and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency (pancreatic diabetes) typically occur late when more than 90% of pancreatic tissue is destroyed.
questions.hint: This patient presents with Courvoisier sign (jaundice and a nontender, palpable gall bladder). Pale stools, dark urine, pruritus (suggested by the scratch marks on this patient's extremities), and direct hyperbilirubinemia indicate posthepatic jaundice.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of progressive jaundice, dark urine, clay-colored stools, and a dull right upper quadrant ache. He denies fevers or chills. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Examination shows scleral icterus but no hepatosplenomegaly. He has no known drug allergies (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Total bilirubin
56 μmol/L
3.5 - 16.5 μmol/L


Alkaline phosphatase
320 IU/L
39 - 117 IU/L


Alanine aminotransferase
50 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
45 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging study to evaluate for the most likely underlying cause of his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) provides detailed visualization of the biliary and pancreatic ducts, useful in complex cases or when initial imaging is inconclusive. However, for initial evaluation of obstructive jaundice, a rapid and widely available imaging study like ultrasound is preferred. MRCP is typically a secondary investigation following initial assessment.

B) INCORRECT:

Contrast-enhanced CT scan provides detailed cross-sectional views for mass lesions and vascular involvement. However, for initial assessment of cholestasis, a noninvasive study like ultrasound is preferred to quickly assess bile duct dilation and obstruction without radiation or contrast exposure.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) allows direct visualization and therapeutic intervention in the biliary tree. However, its invasive nature and risks, such as pancreatitis and perforation, make it unsuitable as an initial imaging study. Noninvasive modalities like ultrasound are preferred first to assess for bile duct dilation or obstruction.

D) CORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected obstructive jaundice due to its noninvasive nature, availability, and cost-effectiveness. It efficiently evaluates biliary dilation, a hallmark of extrahepatic obstruction. In this patient, the elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels suggest a cholestatic pattern, where ultrasound can identify dilated bile ducts or intraductal masses or stones. It also assesses the periampullary region and gallbladder for other pathologies contributing to biliary obstruction, making it the first-line study in evaluating obstructive jaundice.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected biliary obstruction with elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin levels, an abdominal ultrasound is the first-line imaging modality to evaluate for potential causes such as gallstones or bile duct dilation.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with two days of dull right upper quadrant pain radiating to her back. She also reports dark urine and mild generalized pruritus over the last few days. She has no significant past medical history and denies recent alcohol use, drug allergies, or prior surgeries. She is afebrile with normal vital signs. Examination reveals mild scleral icterus and a positive Murphy’s sign. An obstructive biliary process is suspected (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Direct bilirubin
15 μmol/L
1.5 - 6.5 μmol/L


Alkaline phosphatase
250 IU/L
39 - 117 IU/L


Alanine aminotransferase
30 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
35 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging study for this condition?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) offers high-resolution images of the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It is useful when conventional imaging is inconclusive or in complex cases. However, MRCP is not ideal as the first-line imaging due to its cost, availability, and longer acquisition time, making it less suitable for initial assessment of suspected biliary obstruction.

B) CORRECT:

Transabdominal ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging study for suspected biliary obstruction due to its noninvasive nature, availability, and high sensitivity for detecting biliary dilation and gallstones. It effectively visualizes the gallbladder and bile ducts, identifying echogenic foci with acoustic shadowing from gallstones. Ultrasound also assesses gallbladder wall thickening and potential cholecystitis. This imaging modality correlates clinical and laboratory findings, such as elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase, with structural abnormalities indicative of biliary obstruction.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected biliary obstruction, trans-abdominal ultrasonography is the first-line investigation to assess for gallstones and bile duct dilation.

C) INCORRECT:

Contrast-enhanced CT scans provide detailed images of intra-abdominal structures and can identify complications like abscesses or neoplasms. However, CT is less effective for detecting gallstones, especially cholesterol stones, which may be radiolucent. Its spatial resolution for the biliary system is inferior to ultrasound, making it less suitable for initial evaluation of suspected gallstone-induced obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is an invasive procedure allowing diagnostic and therapeutic interventions in the biliary tree. While valuable for immediate intervention, ERCP carries risks such as pancreatitis and perforation. It is not the primary diagnostic tool for stable patients without severe infection or cholangitis, where non-invasive imaging should be prioritized.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with jaundice and mild right upper quadrant pain. His laboratory values show total bilirubin 9.8 mg/dL, direct bilirubin 8.4 mg/dL, AST 78 U/L, ALT 65 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 385 U/L, and GGT 320 U/L. Urinalysis shows elevated bilirubin and absent urobilinogen. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hepatitis panel is appropriate for intrahepatic jaundice with hepatocellular injury. This patient's laboratory values show only mildly elevated aspartate aminotransferase and alanine aminotransferase with markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase, which suggests cholestasis rather than hepatocellular damage. Extrahepatic obstruction should be ruled out first.

B) INCORRECT:

CT abdomen with contrast is second-line imaging for cholestasis when ultrasound is inconclusive or when better anatomic detail is needed. Initial evaluation should begin with the less expensive and more readily available ultrasound examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemolysis workup is indicated for prehepatic jaundice, which manifests with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and elevated urinary urobilinogen. This patient has predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with absent urinary urobilinogen, which suggests cholestasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a therapeutic and diagnostic procedure reserved for when intervention is planned or other imaging modalities are insufficient. ERCP carries procedural risks and is not the initial diagnostic approach when noninvasive imaging can provide the necessary information.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's laboratory pattern shows conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with elevated cholestatic enzymes and absent urinary urobilinogen, consistent with cholestasis. Right upper quadrant ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging study for suspected biliary obstruction to evaluate for ductal dilation and identify potential causes of obstruction.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents with 18 hours of right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice. Vital signs are BP, 92/58; P, 118; R, 18; T, 38.8°C (101.8°F). Laboratory studies show WBC count 16,500/mm3, total bilirubin 7.1 mg/dL, and INR 1.6. Right upper quadrant ultrasound shows multiple stones in the common bile duct with upstream dilatation. Intravenous fluids are started. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Antibiotics within 4–6 hours and ERCP within 24–48 hours
Antibiotics within 1 hour and ERCP within 24 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This timing is appropriate for Grade I–II acute cholangitis. However, this patient has Grade III disease based on hepatic dysfunction (INR > 1.5) and needs more urgent intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical choledochotomy with T-tube placement is considered only as a last resort when minimally invasive endoscopic and percutaneous procedures are unsuccessful or not feasible.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has Grade III acute cholangitis based on organ dysfunction (hepatic dysfunction with INR > 1.5). Antibiotics within 1 hour and urgent biliary drainage within 24 hours are indicated in Grade III disease to achieve rapid source control and prevent further deterioration.

D) INCORRECT:

ERCP is appropriate for this patient, but antibiotics should be initiated first as part of the immediate management of Grade III acute cholangitis, particularly before any invasive procedures.

E) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage is a second-line procedure reserved for when the first-line treatment is unsuccessful or not feasible. A different initial approach is preferred for acute cholangitis.
